Posts.Content: Thanks, Chuck for the quick reply to my post. A fews things I failed to mention: 1. I also have ulcerative colitis. Was diagnosed with it when I was 12. Because of this condition, one of the surgeons I consulted, recommended that I avoid radiation. He stated that radiation can impact the rectum, and I should avoid such with UC. 2. I also take Propecia for the treatment of male pattern hair loss. The uro that performed my biopsy told me that my "true" PSA reading was actually around 9.6. 3. Prostate cancer runs in my family on my father's side. My grandfather and several of his siblings had PC. My father has BPH, and keeps an active check on his prostate. In fact, one of his biopsies came back with HGPIN.
Posts.Title: Looking for information

Posts.Content: Thanks, Newporter, for your input. I have ruled out AS and I have an appointment to see Dr. Tully in Birmingham on December 5.
Posts.Title: Looking for information

Posts.Content: Hi Otago, Thanks for your comments. 1. The biopsy was performed on 10/10/2014. The PSA was taken on 09/19/2014. 2. I don't know why 22 cores were taken. I didn't ask the question just submitted to the torture! It could have been that I also take Propecia for male pattern hair loss. The uro that performed the biopsy told me that my "real" PSA was probably twice the test result. 3. I totally agree with getting a second opinion on the slides. In fact, one of the surgeons I consulted told me that before he performed surgery he wanted his guy to look at the slides, and if the results were different, he would send it to Johns Hopkins for a third analysis.

Posts.Title: Looking for information

Posts.Content: This is my first post to this forum. I am 46 years old, and I was recently diagnosed with prostate cancer. Here is some information from my Surgical Pathology Cancer Case Summary: Histologic Type: Adenocarcinoma (acinar, not otherwise specified) Gleason Pattern: Primary 3, Secondary 3, Total 6 PSA 4.82 This was my first and only PSA Number of cores positive: 2 Total number of cores: 22 Proportion of prostatic tissue involved by tumor: 5% I have seen three surgeons, and each one has told me that due to my age I have two choices: surgery and watchful waiting. I am leaning toward surgery but how does one find a competent surgeon? I have been told that I am an ideal candidate for robotic surgery. I live in North Mississippi (approximately 80 miles from Memphis, TN). My research has led me to the Urology Centers of Alabama in Birmingham. They have nine surgeons who perform robotic surgery. One of the surgeons, Scott Tully, has performed over 3,000 and, according to the website, he routinely performs 8-10 per week. Does anyone have any experience with this organization? Any information you can share with me will be greatly appreciated as I attempt to make a decision.

AgeInfo.Phrase: <Z> <Z> <Z> I am 46 years old  and I was
